title: 112_hr3707
content: The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2011" prohibits consideration of legislation containing earmarks. The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2011" prohibits the inclusion of congressional earmarks, limited tax benefits, or limited tariff benefits in any legislation considered in the House of Representatives. If a point of order is raised and sustained, the earmark or benefit will be removed from the measure. Special procedures apply to conference reports and amendments between the houses. The "Earmark Elimination Act of 2011" prohibits congressional earmarks, tax benefits, or tariff benefits in House legislation. If a point of order is sustained, the earmark or benefit will be removed. Special procedures apply to conference reports and amendments between the houses. The House must decide whether to recede and concur in Senate amendments or insist further on House amendments. Special procedures apply to conference reports and amendments between the houses. The House has privileged motions to consider Senate amendments, including receding and concurring with an amendment, requesting further conference, or insisting on disagreement. If a point of order is raised regarding earmarks or tax benefits, the Chair will determine the provision's classification. The House has privileged motions to consider Senate amendments, including receding and concurring with an amendment, requesting further conference, or insisting on disagreement. If a point of order is raised regarding earmarks or tax benefits, the Chair will determine the provision's classification. In cases of congressional earmarks, limited tax benefits, or limited tariff benefits, the Chair will put the question to the House for a decision without debate or intervening motion. Rule XXI of the Rules of the House of Representatives is amended by striking clause 9. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The curr_chunk defines "congressional earmark" as a provision requesting specific budget authority for a project, and "limited tax benefit" as a tax provision benefiting 10 or fewer entities. The curr_chunk defines "limited tariff benefit" as a provision modifying the Harmonized Tariff Schedule of the United States in a way that benefits 10 or fewer entities.
